PT J
AN ZOOR14705042093
DT Article
TI Review of the native Hawaiian leafhopper genus Nesophrosyne (Hemiptera:
   Cicadellidae: Deltocephalinae) with description of eight new species
   associated with Broussaisia arguta (Hydrangeaceae).
AU Bennett, Gordon M. (gbennett@berkeley.edu) 
   O'Grady, Patrick M.
SO Zootaxa
VL 2805
PS 1-25
PD 30 Mar 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2011/2805.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/f/zt02805p025.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB A review of the native Hawaiian leafhopper genus Nesophrosyne
   (Hemiptera: Cicadellidae: Deltocephalinae) is presented. Specimens were
   examined from across the entire Hawaiian Archipelago, Nesophrosyne is
   redescribed, and the subgenus Nesoreias is synonymized with
   Nesophrosyne. Eight new species associated with the widespread host
   plant species Broussaisia arguta are described: N. heopoko sp. n. from
   Kaua'i; N. makaihe sp. n. from O'ahu; N. magnaccai sp. n. from Moloka'i;
   N. broussaisiai sp. n., N. ogradyi sp. n., and N. kaupoi sp. n. from
   Maui; and, N. aakokohaikea sp. n. and N. kanawao sp. n. from Hawai'i
   Island. Morphological and molecular characters were employed to
   delineate new species. Populations associated with B. arguta on
   different islands, individual volcanic mountains, and discrete
   geographic areas represent reciprocally monophyletic species. A
   monophyletic complex of five sibling species, morphologically cryptic on
   individual islands, were identified from Maui and Hawai'i Island. The
   kanawao species group is erected for these species and is further
   subdivided into two species subgroups based on monophyly, island
   endemicity, and morphology: broussaisiai species subgroup containing N.
   broussaisiai, N. ogradyi, and N. kaupoi on Maui; and, aakokohaikea
   species subgroup containing N. aakokohaikea and N. kanawao on Hawai'i
   Island.
C1 Bennett, Gordon M.; University of California, Berkeley, Department of
   Environmental Science, Policy and Management, 137 Mulford Hall #3114
   Berkeley, CA 94720, USA, USA.
EM gbennett@berkeley.edu
RI Bennett, Gordon/F-9147-2012; O'Grady, Patrick/J-3421-2019
OI O'Grady, Patrick/0000-0002-6075-8951
SC Nutrition &Dietetics; Zoology; Evolutionary Biology; Environmental
   Sciences &Ecology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Description; Synonymy; Taxonomy;
   Key; Nutrition; Diet; Evolution; Associations; Land zones; USA; Oceanic
   islands; Pacific Ocean islands
DE Nesophrosyne [Food plants / Broussaisia arguta / systematics] [Phylogeny
   /  / ] [Associations / Broussaisia arguta (Plant) / Key to associated
   species] [Hawaii /  / Key to species; associated with Broussaisia arguta
   (Plant)] [ /  / ]. 
   Nesophrosyne aakokohaikea; Nesophrosyne broussaisiai; Nesophrosyne
   heopoko; Nesophrosyne kanawao; Nesophrosyne kaupoi; Nesophrosyne
   magnaccai; Nesophrosyne makaihe; Nesophrosyne ogradyi [Hawaii /  / New
   species]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; True Bugs
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Hemiptera, Homoptera, Auchenorrhyncha,
   Cicadelloidea, Cicadellidae
OR Nesophrosyne - Kirkaldy 1907 (Cicadellidae): [Redescription, P. 8; Syn
   nov, Nesophrosyne (Nesoreias) Kirkaldy 1910, p. 8; Key to species,
   Hawaii, Associated with Broussaisia arguta (Plant), p. 9]. 
   Nesophrosyne aakokohaikea - Bennett 2011 (Cicadellidae): [Sp nov,
   Hawaii, P. 19]. 
   Nesophrosyne aakokohaikea species subgroup (Cicadellidae): [New species
   group, P. 18]. 
   Nesophrosyne broussaisiai - Bennett 2011 (Cicadellidae): [Sp nov,
   Hawaii, P. 16]. 
   Nesophrosyne broussaisiai species subgroup (Cicadellidae): [New species
   group, P. 15]. 
   Nesophrosyne heopoko - Bennett 2011 (Cicadellidae): [Sp nov, Hawaii, P.
   10]. 
   Nesophrosyne kanawao - Bennett 2011 (Cicadellidae): [Sp nov, Hawaii, P.
   20]. 
   Nesophrosyne kanawao species group (Cicadellidae): [New species group,
   P. 14]. 
   Nesophrosyne kaupoi - Bennett 2011 (Cicadellidae): [Sp nov, Hawaii, P.
   17]. 
   Nesophrosyne magnaccai - Bennett 2011 (Cicadellidae): [Sp nov, Hawaii,
   P. 13]. 
   Nesophrosyne makaihe - Bennett 2011 (Cicadellidae): [Sp nov, Hawaii, P.
   11]. 
   Nesophrosyne ogradyi - Bennett 2011 (Cicadellidae): [Sp nov, Hawaii, P.
   17]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14705042093

   Neanuridae).
AU Queiroz, Gabriel C. (gabriel_cq@yahoo.com.br) 
   Fernandes, Liliane H.
SO Zootaxa
VL 2805
PS 57-64
PD 30 Mar 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2011/2805.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/1/zt02805p064.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Furculanurida tropicalia sp. nov., is described from leaf litter of the
   Atlantic forest of Southeast Brazil. It is characterized as being the
   first species of the genus that possess 8+8 eyes. New diagnosis and
   remarks on the genus and the species of Furculanurida are made. The
   species Stachorutes arlei is transferred once more from Furculanurida to
   Stachorutes.

DT Article
TI On the genus Raphidrilus Monticelli, 1910 (Polychaeta: Ctenodrilidae)
   with description of two new species.
AU Magalhaes, Wagner F.
   Bailey-Brock, Julie H. (jbrock@hawaii.edu) 
   Davenport, Jennifer S.
SO Zootaxa
VL 2804
PS 1-14
PD 30 Mar 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2011/2804.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/f/zt02804p014.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB Raphidrilus harperi sp. nov., is described from the Gulf Intracoastal
   Waterway (GIWW) in Venice, Florida from sediments consisting of coarse
   sands and shell hash. Raphidrilus hawaiiensis sp. nov., is described
   from Oahu's shallow waters and inhabits a successful invasive alga in
   Waikiki and sandy sediments adjacent to ocean outfalls in Barbers Point
   and Sand Island, off Honolulu. The genus Raphidrilus is emended, the
   distinctness between the genera Raricirrus and Raphidrilus is confirmed
   and keys to all recognized genera of Ctenodrilidae and species of
   Raphidrilus are given.

   Manoa, 2538 McCarthy Mall, Honolulu, Hawaii, 96822, USA, USA.

DT Article
TI The Indian species of Liophloeothrips Priesner (Thysanoptera,
   Phlaeothripidae) with one new species.
AU Tayagi, Kaomud (kumud.tyagi5@gmail.com) 
   Kumar, Vikas
SO Zootaxa
VL 2803
PS 21-31
PD 29 Mar 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2011/2803.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/1/zt02803p031.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Liophloeothrips Priesner is a small genus of leaf-feeding
   Phlaeothripidae that is related to the widespread genera Gynaikothrips
   and Liothrips. A key is presented to distinguish these three genera,
   together with a key to, and review of, the 13 species now recognized in
   Liophloeothrips from India. Liophloeothrips acaciae sp. n. is described
   from Karnataka State, collected from the dry flowers, leaves and bark of
   Acacia auriculiformis. Liophloeothrips tenebrosus Ananthakrishnan &
   Jagadish is placed as a new synonym of L. pavettae Ananthakrishnan &
   Jagadish. A lectotype is designated for Liophloeo- thrips cecidii
   Ananthakrishnan 1964.
C1 Tayagi, Kaomud; Division of Biosystematics, Biodiversity and Biosafety,
   National Bureau of Agriculturally Important Insects, Bangalore,
   Karnataka, India, India.
EM kumud.tyagi5@gmail.com

   parasite species] [Karnataka /  / New species from plant host].

TI Revision of Emphytopsis Wei & Nie (Hymenoptera: Tenthredinidae) with
   descriptions of seven new species from China and Japan.
AU Wei, Meicai (weimc@126.com) 
   Xu, Yi
   Niu, Gengyun
SO Zootaxa
VL 2803
PS 1-20
PD 29 Mar 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2011/2803.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/1/zt02803p020.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Emphytopsis Wei & Nie, 1998 of Allantinae, Tenthredinidae is revised.
   Seven species are described as new: Emphytopsis nigricornis Wei & Xu,
   sp. nov., E. quadrata Wei & Xu, sp. nov., E. unimaculata Wei, sp. nov.,
   E. zhongi Wei & Niu, sp. nov., E. lii Wei, sp. nov. from China, E.
   shinoharai Wei & Niu, sp. nov. and E. flatoserrula Wei, sp. nov. from
   Japan. E. nigromaculata (Takeuchi, 1952) new combination is transferred
   from Taxonus Hartig. A key to the species of the genus is presented.
   Emphytopsis punctata Wei & Nie, 1998 and E. nigromaculata (Takeuchi) are
   redescribed. The previously unknown male of E. punctata is described.

   localities in the Mexican state of Veracruz and discussed in relation to

   transferred to the subgenus Knulliobuprestis: B. bergevini Thery 1911,

   Obenberger 1928, and B. panamensis Thery 1923 (synonym: B. panamensis
   var. nigripennis Thery 1934).

DT Article
TI Revision of the maculata-group of Phyllodromica: species from Central
   Europe (Insecta: Blattodea: Blattellidae: Ectobiinae).
AU Bohn, Horst (bohn@zi.biologie.uni-muenchen.de) 
   Chladek, Frantisek
SO Arthropod Systematics and Phylogeny
VL 69
IS 1
PS 3-54
PD 28 March 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB The Central European species of the maculata-group of Phyllodromica are
   revised comprising six known species (Phyllodromica chladeki, P. harzi,
   P. hungarica, P. maculata, P. marani, and P. transylvanica) and three
   new species (P. latipennis from Slovakia and Hungary, P. halterisignata
   and P. variabilis from Romania). A short characterization of the group
   is given and all species are described and depicted with their main
   characteristics; the geographic distribution of the species is shown on
   several maps; determination keys allow the identification of males and
   females. P. dobsiki has turned out to be a junior synonym of P.
   hungarica. Similarly, the name Blatta maculata Schreber, 1781, is most
   likely a junior synonym of Blatta schaefferi Goeze, 1778; the authors
   propose to consider schaefferi as a nomen dubium and to retain maculata
   as the valid name.
C1 Bohn, Horst; Zool Staatssammlung Munchen, Munchhausenstr 21, Munich,
   Germany, Germany.
EM bohn@zi.biologie.uni-muenchen.de
SC Zoology; Evolutionary Biology
SN 1863-7221

   Key; Evolution; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Europe

DT Article
TI First record of the genus Disholcaspis Dalla Torre & Kieffer
   (Hymenoptera: Cynipidae: Cynipini) in the Neotropics, with description
   of two new species from Panama.
AU Medianero, Enrique
   Nieves-Aldrey, Jose Luis (emedianero@ancon.up.ac.pa) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 2802
PS 23-33
PD 28 Mar 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2011/2802.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/1/zt02802p033.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Two new species of Disholcaspis Dalla Torre & Kieffer 1910, Disholcaspis
   bettyannae and D. bisethiae (Hymenoptera: Cynipidae: Cynipini) are
   described from Panama. The two new species induce galls on Quercus
   bumelioides Liebm. and Q. lancifolia Schledl & Cham. (Fagaceae, sect.
   Quercus, White Oaks). Diagnostic characters, gall descriptions,
   distribution, biological data, as well as inquiline and parasitoid
   associated community data of the new species are given. The new species
   represent the first records of the genus Disholcaspis from the
   Neotropical region.
C1 Nieves-Aldrey, Jose Luis; Museo Nacional de Ciencias Naturales (CSIC),

TI A new Aphidius Nees (Hymenoptera, Braconidae, Aphidiinae) of Ericaphis
   fimbriata (Richards) (Hemiptera, Aphididae) and key to parasitoids of
   blueberry aphid in the Pacific Northwest.
AU Pike, Keith S. (kpike@wsu.edu) 
   Stary, Petr
   Graf, George
   Raworth, David A.
   Mathur, Sneh
   Tanigoshi, Lynell K.
   Murray, Todd

LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Aphidius ericaphidis Pike & Stary, sp. nov., is described and
   illustrated. This aphidiine is a parasitoid of the blueberry aphid,
   Ericaphis fimbriata (Richards), widely found associated with the
   commercial highbush blueberries, Vaccinium corymbosum L., in
   southwestern British Columbia, Washington, and in northeastern Oregon.
   It is one of several species of aphidiines known to attack E. fimbriata
   in North America. A key is provided to distinguish it from other
   parasitoid species of E. fimbriata.

AN ZOOR14705042083
DT Article
TI A study of the scale insect genera Puto Signoret (Hemiptera:
   Sternorrhyncha: Coccoidea: Putoidae) and Ceroputo Sulc (Pseudococcidae)
   with a comparison to Phenacoccus Cockerell (Pseudococcidae).
AU Williams, D.J.
   Gullan, P.J. (pjgullan@ucdavis.edu) 
   Miller, D.R.
   Matile-Ferrero, D.
   Han, Sarah I.
SO Zootaxa
VL 2802
PS 1-22
PD 28 Mar 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2011/2802.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/f/zt02802p022.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB For almost a century, the scale insect genus Puto Signoret (Hemiptera:
   Sternorrhyncha: Coccoidea) was considered to belong to the family
   Pseudococcidae (the mealybugs), but recent consensus accords Puto its
   own family, the Putoidae. This paper reviews the taxonomic history of
   Puto and family Putoidae, compares the morphology of Puto to that of
   Ceroputo Sulc and Phenacoccus Cockerell, and reassesses the status of
   all species that have been placed in Puto to determine whether they
   belong to the Putoidae or to the Pseudococcidae. For 49 of 57 species
   that have been placed in Puto, as listed in the online database
   ScaleNet, we score and tabulate features that are diagnostic for
   Putoidae and then list all species in their correct family placement.
   For comparison, we include a few species of Pseudococcidae, namely five
   species of Phenacoccus, including the type species Phenacoccus aceris
   (Signoret), and the type species of Ceroputo, C. pilosellae Sulc. We
   provide revised synonymy lists for Puto and Ceroputo, a brief diagnosis
   of each genus, synonymy lists and notes for several species for which we
   suggest recombinations or additional synonyms, or for which we have
   additional data on morphology. We provide a brief diagnosis of
   Phenacoccus for comparison with Ceroputo and Puto. As a result of our
   study, we recognise 47 extant and two fossil species of Puto, and six
   species of Ceroputo. The New World species Puto mimicus McKenzie and
   Puto nulliporus McKenzie are transferred to the mealybug genus Ceroputo
   as Ceroputo mimicus (McKenzie) comb. nov. and Ceroputo nulliporus
   (McKenzie) comb. nov., respectively, and the Old World species Puto pini
   Danzig and Puto vaccinii Danzig are recognised as Ceroputo pini (Danzig)
   comb. rev. and Ceroputo vaccinii (Danzig) comb. rev., respectively, in
   agreement with Tang (1992). The Old World species Puto graminis Danzig
   is transferred to Ceroputo as Ceroputo graminis (Danzig) comb. nov.
   Based only on a study of the literature, the following two names are
   treated here as junior subjective synonyms of Ceroputo pilosellae:
   Phenacoccus asteri Takahashi syn. nov. and Puto jarudensis Tang syn.
   nov. We agree with Tang (1992) that Leococcus erigeroneus Kanda should
   be treated as a junior subjective synonym of C. pilosellae and thus the
   genus name Leococcus Kanda, erected for L. erigeroneus and formerly
   treated as a junior synonym of Puto, is a junior synonym of Ceroputo.
C1 Gullan, P.J.; Department of Entomology, University of California, One
   Shields Avenue, Davis, CA 95616, USA, USA.
EM pjgullan@ucdavis.edu
SC Zoology; Anatomy &Morphology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Combination; Synonymy; Taxonomy; Taxonomic
   position; General morphology
DE Pseudococcidae; Puto; Putoidae [General morphology /  / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; True Bugs
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Hemiptera, Homoptera, Sternorrhyncha,
   Coccoidea
OR Ceroputo - Sulc 1897 (Coccoidea): [Diagnosis, P. 14; Senior synonym, Of
   Leococcus Kanda 1959, p. 16]. 
   Ceroputo graminis - (Danzig 1972) (Coccoidea): [Comb nov, Transferred
   from Puto, p. 15]. 
   Ceroputo mimicus - (McKenzie 1967) (Coccoidea): [Comb nov, Transferred
   from Puto, p. 15]. 
   Ceroputo nulliporus - (McKenzie 1960) (Coccoidea): [Comb nov,
   Transferred from Puto, p. 15]. 
   Ceroputo pilosellae - Sulc 1898 (Coccoidea): [Syn nov, Phenacoccus
   asteri Takahashi 1932, p. 16; Syn nov, Puto jarudensis Tang 1992, p.
   16]. 
   Ceroputo pini - (Danzig 1972) (Coccoidea): [Combination revalidated,
   Transferred back from Puto, p. 17]. 
   Ceroputo vaccinii - (Danzig 1978) (Coccoidea): [Combination revalidated,
   Transferred back from Puto, p. 17]. 
   Leococcus - Kanda 1959 (Coccoidea): [Junior synonym, Of Ceroputo Sulc
   1897, p. 16]. 
   Phenacoccus - Cockerell 1893 (Coccoidea): [Diagnosis, P. 18]. 
   Pseudococcidae (Coccoidea). 
   Puto - Signoret 1875 (Coccoidea): [Diagnosis, P. 11; Taxonomy, Taxonomic
   history, p. 9]. 
   Puto graminis - Danzig 1972 (Coccoidea): [Referred to, Ceroputo, p. 15].
   
   Puto mimicus - McKenzie 1967 (Coccoidea): [Referred to, Ceroputo, p.
   15]. 
   Puto nulliporus - McKenzie 1960 (Coccoidea): [Referred to, Ceroputo, p.
   15]. 
   Puto pini - Danzig 1972 (Coccoidea): [Referred to, Ceroputo, p. 17]. 
   Puto vaccinii - Danzig 1978 (Coccoidea): [Referred to, Ceroputo, p. 17].
   
   Putoidae (Coccoidea). 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14705042083
DA 2020-09-17

PM 21436452
DT Article
TI Dental Occlusion in a 260-Million-Year-Old Therapsid with Saber Canines
   from the Permian of Brazil.
AU Cisneros, Juan Carlos
   Abdala, Fernando
   Rubidge, Bruce S.
   Dentzien-Dias, Paula Camboim
   Bueno, Ana de Oliveira
SO Science (Washington D C)
VL 331
IS 6024
PS 1603-1605
PD Mar 25 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 12
AB Anomodonts, a group of herbivorous therapsid "mammal-like reptiles,"
   were the most abundant tetrapods of the Permian. We present a basal
   anomodont from South America, a new taxon that has transversally
   expanded palatal teeth and long saber canines. The function of the saber
   teeth is unknown, but probable uses include deterring attack from
   predators and intraspecific display or combat. The complex palatal teeth
   were used to process high-fiber food and represent early evidence of
   dental occlusion in a therapsid. This discovery provides new insight
   into the evolution of heterogeneous dentition in therapsids and broadens
   our understanding of ecological interactions at the end of the
   Paleozoic.
C1 Cisneros, Juan Carlos; Univ Fed Piaui, Ctr Ciencias Nat, Teresina,
   Piaui, Brazil, Brazil.
RI Rubidge, Bruce/AAE-7021-2019; Abdala, Fernando/I-8054-2019
OI Rubidge, Bruce/0000-0003-2477-1873; Cisneros, Juan
   Carlos/0000-0001-6159-1981
SC Zoology; Anatomy &Morphology; Evolutionary Biology
SN 0036-8075
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Taxonomic position;
   Skeletal and supporting structures; Skeleton; Dentition; Evolution; Land
   zones; Neotropical region; South America; Geological time periods;
   Palaeozoic
DE Anomocephaloidea [Permian /  / New clade]. 
   Anomodontia [Dentition / Dentition description / ] [Teeth / Saber
   canines / ] [Evolution / Dental occlusion evolution / ] [Brazil /  / ]
   [Permian /  / ]. 
   Therapsida [Phylogeny / Stratigraphically calibrated phylogeny / ]
   [Permian /  / ]. 
   Tiarajudens [Permian /  / New genus]. 
   Tiarajudens eccentricus [Brazil /  / new species] [Permian /  / ]. 
TN Chordates; Reptiles; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Reptilia, Synapsida, Therapsida
OR Therapsida (Synapsida): [Fossil]. 
   Anomocephaloidea (Therapsida): [Taxon nov, New clade of Anomodontia, For
   Anomocephalus & Tiarajudens (new), p. 1605, Permian; Fossil]. 
   Anomocephalus (Therapsida): [Referred to, New clade Anomocephaloidea, p.
   1605; Fossil]. 
   Anomodontia (Therapsida): [Fossil]. 
   Tiarajudens (Therapsida): [Gen nov, Of new clade (higher taxon)

DT Article
TI Revision of the genus Alonopsis Sars, 1862 and its position within
   Aloninae (Cladocera: Anomopoda: Chydoridae).
AU Sinev, Artem Y. (artemsinev@yandex.ru) 
   Atroschenko, Margarita M.
SO Zootaxa
VL 2800
PS 1-17
PD 25 Mar 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2011/2800.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/2/zt02800p017.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Taxonomic status of the genus Alonopsis was clarified by the
   morphological study and cladistic analysis. Morphology of both valid
   species, A. elongata (Sars, 1861) and A. aureolata Doolitle, 1912, was
   investigated. So far, generic status of the group was questioned, some
   authors treated Alonopsis as a part of the genus Acroperus. Our data
   confirm independent status of Alonopsis, and emended diagnosis of the
   genus is provided. According to our analysis, Acroperus and Alonopsis
   are the sister-groups of a monophyletic clade, each having their own
   autapomorphies. Both genera belong to a well-defined group of Aloninae
   (named here as Arthrocauda-group), which is characterized by the
   presence of well-developed abdominal joint and elongated narrow
   postabdomen. There are two parallel clades within the group, one formed
   by Acroperus and Alonopsis, other by Parakozhowia, Kozhowia and
   Camptocercus. According to our analysis, these branches have numerous
   homoplasies, the most significant of them is the independent appearance
   of the head keel in two most successful genera, Acroperus and
   Camptocercus.
C1 Sinev, Artem Y.; Department of Invertebrate Zoology, Biological Faculty,
   M. V. Lomonosov Moscow State University, Leninskie Gory, Moscow 119992,
   Russia, Russia.
EM artemsinev@yandex.ru
SC Anatomy &Morphology; Zoology; Evolutionary Biology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Taxonomy; Taxonomic
   position; General morphology; Evolution
DE Aloninae [General morphology /  / systematics] [Phylogeny / Cladistics /
   ]. 
TN Arthropods; Crustaceans; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Crustacea, Branchiopoda, Cladocera
OR Acroperus (Cladocera): [Referred to, New genus group Arthrocauda, p.
   14]. 
   Aloninae (Cladocera). 
   Alonopsis - Sars 1862 (Cladocera): [Revision, P. 4; Emended diagnosis,
   P. 4; Referred to, New genus group Arthrocauda, p. 14]. 
   Arthrocauda (Cladocera): [Taxon nov, New genus group, p. 14]. 
   Camptocercus (Cladocera): [Referred to, New genus group Arthrocauda, p.
   14]. 
   Kozhowia (Cladocera): [Referred to, New genus group Arthrocauda, p. 14].
   
   Parakozhowia (Cladocera): [Referred to, New genus group Arthrocauda, p.
   14]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14705041448
DA 2020-09-17

PT J
AN ZOOR14705041450
DT Article
TI Halacarus socius (Acari: Halacaridae), description of the male and
   diagnoses of species of the Halacarus actenos group.
AU Bartsch, Ilse (bartsch@meeresforschung.de) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 2800
PS 19-40
PD 25 Mar 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2011/2800.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/2/zt02800p040.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Amongst the about a dozen halacarid species from a shore of Mauritius,
   the genus Halacarus was represented by a single species, Halacarus
   socius Bartsch, 1992. The species was once described on the basis of
   females collected on Moorea, Society Islands, Pacific Ocean, now a
   description of the male is added and that of the female supplemented.
   Halacarus socius seems to be wide-spread in the Indo-Pacific region.
   Halacarus tritoni Otto is a synonym. Halacarus socius is a member of the
   H. actenos group, a group characterized by the combination: posterior
   dorsal plate absent in both females and males, ocular plates small or
   lacking, with or without a cornea, apodemes of anterior and posterior
   epimeral plates long, female genitoanal plate with rather uniform
   cerotegumental cover and two pairs of perigenital setae adjacent to the
   genital opening, one pair (rarely two pairs) of perigenital setae
   anterior to the genitoanal plate, one or two bipectinate setae on tibia
   II, no tines on shaft of claws but paired claws often with tines on the
   accessory process. Species attributed to this group are diagnosed.
C1 Bartsch, Ilse; Forschungsinstitut Senckenberg, Notkestr. 85, 22607
   Hamburg, Germany, Germany.
EM bartsch@meeresforschung.de
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Description; Synonymy; Zoogeography; Marine
   zones; Indian Ocean; Pacific Ocean
DE Halacarus actenos group [Zoogeography /  / ]. 
   Halacarus socius [North Indian Ocean / Sri Lanka / New record;
   systematics] [South Indian Ocean / Mauritius / ] [North Pacific /
   Indonesia, Sulawesi / ]. 
TN Arachnids; Arthropods; Chelicerates; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Arachnida, Acari
OR Halacarus actenos group (Acari): [Systematics, P. 23]. 
   Halacarus socius - Bartsch 1992 (Acari): [First time described, Males,
   p. 21; Redescription, Female, p. 19; Syn nov, Halacarus tritoni Otto
   2001, p. 19; New record]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14705041450
DA 2020-09-17

   are reported. Photographs of the dorsal habitus and figures of the male
   genitalia of genus Hypseloecus are given. The type specimens are
   deposited in the Institute of Entomology, Nankai University, Tianjin,
   China. New records for China are Hypseloecus takahashii Yasunaga, 2001,
   Cimidaeorus hasegawai Nakatani, Yasunaga & Takai, 2000, Deraeocoris
   (Camptobrochis) orientalis (Distant, 1904), D. (Deraeocoris) ainoicus
   Kerzhner, 1979, D. (D.) kimotoi Miyamoto, 1965, D. (D.) sanghonami Lee &
   Kerzhner, 1995, D. (D.) yasunagai Nakatani, 1995, D. (Knightocapsus)
   elegantulus Horvath, 1905, Fingulus apoensis Stonedahl & Cassis, 1991,
   F. collaris Miyamoto, 1965, F. umbonatus Stonedahl & Cassis, 1991,
   Stethoconus pyri (Mella, 1869), S. rhoksane Linnavuori, 1995 and
   Termatophylum hikosanum Miyamoto, 1965.

TI Taxonomy of the Butterfly Genus Cepora Billberg (Lepidoptera: Pieridae)
   from China.
AU Ding, Chang-ping
   Shang, Su-qin (suqinsh@126.com) 
   Zhang, Ya-lin
SO Entomotaxonomia
VL 33
IS 1
PS 32-40
PD Mar 25 2011
PY 2011
LA Chinese
U1 0
U2 1
AB The butterfly genus Cepora is reviewed, of which one known species is
   synonymized: Cepora wui Chou and Zhang, 2001 (= Delias levicki
   Rothschild, 1927), which is the first record of Delias levicki from
   China. Illustrations including male, female genitalia, adults and veins
   are provided, the key to Chinese species and subspecies are proposed,
   and the geographical distribution is analyzed as well. All specimens
   examined are deposited in the Entomological Museum of Northwest A & F
   University.

DT Article
TI A review of some ecto-and endo protozoan parasites infecting
   Sarotherodon galilaeus and Tilapia zillii from Damietta Branch of River
   Nile, Egypt.
AU Reda, Enayat Salem Ahmed (enayatsalem40@yahoo.com) 
SO Journal of American Science
VL 7
IS 3
PS 362-373
PD March 25 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The present study was carried out as a general survey searching for the
   possible protozoan parasites that can infect the Nile fishes S.
   galilaeus and T. zillii. A total of 125 live fish specimens were
   obtained from Damietta branch of River Nile and El-Sahel canal, Nile
   tributary. Examination of the investigated fish species revealed that,
   fishes were infected with eleven parasitic protozoan species belonging
   to eight genera. These species were: Apiosoma piscicolum, A. conica,
   Scopulata epibranchialis, Vorticella sp., Ambiphrya ameiuri, Amphileptus
   sp., Chilodonella hexasticha, Tetrahymena corlissi, Trypanosoma
   mansouri, T. syanophilum and Trypanosoma sp. Among the obtained
   parasites, the following were recovered for the first time in Egypt.
   Apiosoma conica, Vorticella sp., Ambiphrya ameiuri, Amphileptus sp.,
   Tetrahymena corlissi and Trypanosoma sp. While S. galilaeus represent a
   new host for Chilodonella hexasticha. The recorded numerous parasites
   have pathological effects on the host fish with subsequent economic
   losses were discussed.
C1 Reda, Enayat Salem Ahmed; Department of Zoology, Faculty of Science,
   Mansoura University, Mansoura, Egypt, Egypt.
EM enayatsalem40@yahoo.com
SC Cell Biology; Zoology; Parasitology; Marine &Freshwater Biology;
   Environmental Sciences &Ecology
SN 1545-1003
BD Cytology; Parasites diseases and disorders; Parasites; Hosts; Habitat;
   Freshwater habitat; Lotic water; Land zones; Afrotropical region;
   Palaearctic region; Africa
DE Protozoa [General cell ultrastructure /  / host parasite list] [Piscean
   hosts / Sarotherodon galilaeus / ] [ / Tilapia zillii / ] [River /  / ]
   [Egypt / River Nile, Damietta branch / ] [River Nile / Egypt, Damietta
   Branch / ]. 
   Sarotherodon galilaeus; Tilapia zillii [Protozoan parasites /  / Host
   parasite list; parasite morphology] [River /  / ] [Egypt / River Nile,
   Damietta branch / ] [River Nile / Egypt, Damietta Branch / ]. 
TN Chordates; Fish; Protozoans; Vertebrates

   Perciformes, Cichlidae, Protozoa
OR Protozoa: [Parasite]. 
   Sarotherodon galilaeus (Cichlidae): [Host].

AN ZOOR14705041441
DT Article
TI The genus Hydroptila Dalman (Trichoptera, Hydroptilidae) in Japan.
AU Ito, Tomiko (tobikera@siren.ocn.ne.jp) 
   Ohkawa, Ayuko
   Hattori, Toshio
SO Zootaxa
VL 2801
PS 1-26
PD 25 Mar 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2011/2801.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/f/zt02801p026.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB The Japanese species of Hydroptila Dalman (Trichoptera, Hydroptilidae)
   are reviewed, confirming 10 described species, and introducing 2 new
   species. For clear comparisons and to include new details, males and
   females of all species, including the 2 new species, H. ogasawaraensis
   Ito and H. nanseiensis Ito, are redescribed or described anew.
   Hydroptila itoi Kobayashi is synonymized with H. dampfi Ulmer and H.
   thuna Olah and H. botosaneanui Kumanski are recorded for the Japanese
   fauna for the first time. Hydroptila usuguronis Matsumura is reassigned
   to the genus Psychomyia Latreille (Psychomyiidae).
C1 Ito, Tomiko; Hokkaido Aquatic Biology, Hakuyo-cho, 3-3-5, Eniwa,
   Hokkaido, 061-1434, Japan, Japan.
EM tobikera@siren.ocn.ne.jp

DT Article
TI Revision of the genus Paraspicera Kieffer, 1907 (Hym: Figitidae:
   Aspicerinae).
AU Ros-Farre, P.
   Pujade-Villar, J. (jpujade@ub.edu) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 2801
PS 48-56
PD 25 Mar 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2011/2801.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/1/zt02801p056.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Paraspicera Kieffer, 1907 is a genus of Aspicerinae (Hymenoptera:
   Cynipoidea: Figitidae) of Nearctic distribution that includes a small
   number of species. The diagnostic characters to differentiate
   Paraspicera from other similar genera are described. From the five known
   species of Paraspicera only P. bakeri Kieffer, 1907 belongs to
   Paraspicera; the other species are transferred to the genus Aspicera
   Dahlbom, 1842: A. clarimontis Kieffer rev. status, A. uthaensis Ashmead
   rev. status, A. foveata (Belizin) n. comb., and A. kerzhneri (Kovalev)
   n. comb. Paraspicera bakeri is redescribed and a new species is
   described: P. brandaoi n. sp. The diagnostic characters of both species
   are illustrated. The genus Heteraspidia Belizin, 1952 is synonymyzed
   with Aspicera.
C1 Pujade-Villar, J.; Universitat de Barcelona, Facultat de Biologia,
   Departament de Biologia Animal, Avda. Diagonal, 645, E-08028-Barcelona,
   Spain, Spain.
EM jpujade@ub.edu
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334

   Combination; Synonymy; Taxonomy; Taxonomic position; Key; Land zones;
   Nearctic region; North America; Canada; USA
DE Paraspicera brandaoi [Alberta /  / New species] [British Columbia /  / ]

ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Hymenoptera, Apocrita, Terebrantia,
   Cynipoidea, Cynipidae

   revalidated, Transferred back from Paraspicera, p. 54].

   from Paraspicera, p. 55]. 
   Aspicera kerzhneri - (Kovalev 1974) (Cynipidae): [Comb nov, Transferred

DT Article
TI Two new species of Syllidae (Annelida: Polychaeta) from the Southern
   Mexican Pacific.
AU Oropeza, Diana L. Salcedo (rinoa_285@yahoo.com.mx) 
   San Martin, Guillermo
   Solis-Weiss, Vivianne
SO Zootaxa
VL 2800
PS 41-52
PD 25 Mar 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2011/2800.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/2/zt02800p052.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB As part of a project dealing with soft bottom polychaetes from the
   western coasts of Acapulco Bay, Southern Mexican Pacific, 1050 specimens
   of the family Syllidae were collected and identified. Among them, 72
   belong to two new species that are herein described. Plakosyllis
   curvispina n. sp. (31 specimens) is the fourth known species of the
   genus, which is newly recorded for the Mexican Pacific. It is
   characterized by having compound falcigers with elongated blades, very
   long, fine and curved spines, and three antennae in ventral position,
   partially or completely covered by the prostomium. Trypanosyllis
   microdenticulata n. sp. (41 specimens) is characterized by having
   bidentate chaetae, two pairs of eyes, the anterior one in ventral
   position and the posterior one in dorsal position and a very small
   trepan with transparent teeth.
C1 Oropeza, Diana L. Salcedo; Laboratorio de Ecologia y Biodiversidad de
   Invertebrados Marinos, Instituto de Ciencias del Mar y Limnologia,
   Universidad Nacional Autonoma de Mexico, Apartado Postal 70-305, C.P.
   04510, Distrito Federal, Mexico, Mexico.
EM rinoa_285@yahoo.com.mx
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Marine zones; Pacific Ocean
DE Plakosyllis [North Pacific / Mexico / New record]. 
   Plakosyllis curvispina; Trypanosyllis microdenticulata [North Pacific /
   Mexico / New species]. 
TN Annelids; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Annelida, Polychaeta
OR Plakosyllis (Polychaeta): [New record]. 
   Plakosyllis curvispina (Polychaeta): [Sp nov, Mexico (marine), P. 43].

   P. 46].

DT Article
TI A new species of Hemipteroseius (Acari: Otopheidomenidae) parasitic on
   Dysdercus (Hemiptera: Pyrrhocoridae) in India.
AU Menon, Pratibha (pratibharish@gmail.com) 
   Joshi, Sushila
   Hussain, Mohammad
   Ramamurthy, V.V.
SO Zootaxa
VL 2800
PS 53-63
PD 25 Mar 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2011/2800.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/f/zt02800p063.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB A new species of ectoparasitic mite, Hemipteroseius vikrami n. sp.
   (Mesostigmata: Otopheidomenidae), collected on Dysdercus koenigii
   (Fabricius) in New Delhi and D. cingulatus (Fabricius) in Varanasi,
   India is described. It is distinguished from other species of the genus
   in having the dorsal shield divided, podonotal shield with nine pairs
   and opisthonotal shield with four pairs of setae; setae j6, s6 and Z5
   with bulbose/spatulate tips; tritosternum with two short slightly barbed
   lacinae; venter with four pairs of sternal setae, one pair on the
   sternal shield and three pairs placed posterolaterally; anus terminal;
   one pair of preanal setae; movable digit of chelicera with two teeth
   distally; macrosetae on genu I[long dash]IV and femur I[long dash]II
   with bulbose/spatulate tip. A list of species of Otopheidomenidae with
   details of distribution and hosts, key to species of Hemipteroseius and
   comparison of morphological characters of species are also provided.
C1 Menon, Pratibha; Network Project on Insect Biosystematics, Division of
   Entomology, Indian Agricultural Research Institute, New Delhi 110012,
   India, India.
EM pratibharish@gmail.com

DT Article
TI A new species of Iothia (Gastropoda: Lepetidae) from Chilean methane
   seeps, with comments on the accompanying gastropod fauna.
AU Waren, Anders (anders.waren@nrm.se) 
   Nakano, Tomoyuki
   Sellanes, Javier
SO Nautilus
VL 125
IS 1
PS 1-14
PD Mar 24 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 6
AB A new species of the limpet genus Iothia, I. megalodon new species, is
   described from a cold-seep locality, in central Chile. It differs from
   other species of Iothia by the enlarged functional radular teeth. Iothia
   megalodon feeds on bacterial film and sediment as indicated by the gut
   content. Iothia emarginuloides (Philippi, 1868) is re-instated as the
   name to be used for the Antarctic South American species previously
   known as Iothia coppingeri (E.A. Smith, 1881). A COI analysis of eight
   species of Lepetidae is included to elucidate the generic position of
   the new species. The gastropod fauna of the type locality, the recently
   discovered bathyal methane seeps off Central Chile, is reviewed in order
   to place Iothia megalodon in its ecological context. Margarites huloti
   Vilvens, 2006, Bathybembix macdonaldi (Dall, 1891), Calliotropis
   ceciliae Vilvens and Sellanes, 2019, and Cantrainea panamense (Dall,
   1908) are known to have relatives in seeps or other chemosynthetic
   environments. The presence of I. megalodon within this community and its
   gut content support its inclusion as a member of the seep fauna.
C1 Waren, Anders; Swedish Museum Nat Hist, Box 50007, Stockholm, Sweden,
   Sweden.
EM anders.waren@nrm.se
RI Sellanes, Javier/P-4699-2019; Sellanes, Javier/I-5722-2012
OI Sellanes, Javier/0000-0002-6942-0762; Sellanes,
   Javier/0000-0002-6942-0762

   Iothia megalodon [South Pacific / Chile / New species].

DT Article
TI Descriptions and illustrations of some new and poorly known turrids
   (Turridae) of the tropical northwestern Atlantic. Part 2. Genus
   Crassispira Swainson, 1840 subgenera Monilispira Bartsch and Rehder,
   1939 and Dallspira Bartsch, 1950.
AU Fallon, Phillip J., Jr (pfallon@optonline.net) 
SO Nautilus
VL 125
IS 1
PS 15-28
PD Mar 24 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Notes, supplemental or new descriptions, and illustrations are provided
   for nine small, less than 10 mm in height crassispirine turrids in the
   genus Crassispira Swainson, 1840, subgenera Monilispira Bartsch and
   Rehder, 1939 and Dallspira Bartsch, 1950 of the tropical northwestern
   Atlantic. Most are relatively unknown because of the unavailability of
   quality figures and adequate descriptions; one is previously
   undescribed. This group has been a source of confusion to workers
   attempting to identify material collected in recent decades. Each is
   treated systematically, including synonyms, description, variability in
   form, distinguishing characteristics. and geographic range. Species in
   the subgenus Monilispira include Crassispira mayaguanaensis, new
   species, C. latizonata (E.A. Smith, 1882), C. nigrescens (C. B. Adams,
   1845), C. elatior (C. B. Adams, 1845), C. verbernei de Jong and Coomans,
   1988, C. pellisphocae (Reeve, 1845), and C. guildingii (Reeve, 1845).
   Species in the subgenus Dallspira include C. flavocincta (C. B. Adams,
   1850), C. fuscocincta (C. B. Adams. 1850), and C. bandata (Usticke,
   1969). A few notes are made regarding C. fuscocincta; however, this
   species is still an enigma because no specimen has been acquired for
   comparative study.
C1 Fallon, Phillip J., Jr; 77 Cedar Dr, Farmingdale, NY, USA, USA.
EM pfallon@optonline.net
SC Zoology
SN 0028-1344

   Atlantic

   Crassispira (Monilispira) mayaguanaensis [Caribbean Sea / Bahamas / New
   species] [ / Turks and Caicos Islands / ].

DT Article
TI New fossil Bathymodiolus (sensu lato) (Bivalvia: Mytilidae) from
   Oligocene seep-carbonates in eastern Hokkaido, Japan, with remarks on
   the evolution of the genus.
AU Amano, Kazutaka (amano@juen.ac.jp) 
   Jenkins, Robert G.
SO Nautilus
VL 125
IS 1
PS 29-35
PD Mar 24 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB A new species of the genus Bathymodiolus (sensu lato) is herein
   described from the lower Oligocene Nnibetsu Formation in eastern
   Hokkaido, Japan. This is the oldest species of this genus in Japan and
   the second oldest world wide. Based on occurrence and distribution of
   fossil Bathymodiolus (sensu lato), we suggest that the "genus" spread to
   the whole world by the late Miocene. This dispersal pattern is supported
   by molecular studies and similar to that of the large vesicomyids.
C1 Amano, Kazutaka; Joetsu Univ Educ, Dept Geosci, Joetsu, Japan, Japan.
EM amano@juen.ac.jp
RI Jenkins, Robert G/A-8006-2011
OI Jenkins, Robert G/0000-0003-1347-9041
SC Zoology; Evolutionary Biology; Paleontology
SN 0028-1344

DT Article
TI Dillwynella voightae new species, a new skeneimorph gastropod
   (Turbinidae) from the western Atlantic and a new record of Dillwynella
   modesta (Dall, 1889).
AU Kunze, Thomas (kunze@bio.lmu.de) 
SO Nautilus
VL 125
IS 1
PS 36-40
PD Mar 24 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB Dillwynella is a marine gastropod genus found on natural wood falls and
   sunken algal holdfasts in the Caribbean Sea and the Pacific Ocean.
   Dillwynella voightae new species from the Gulf of Mexico was the second
   species found in the Atlantic. Previously known only from two localities
   in the Caribbean Sea. D. modesta (Dall, 1889) has now been recorded at a
   third site off southeastern Brazil.
C1 Kunze, Thomas; Swedish Museum Nat Hist, Box 50007, Stockholm, Sweden,
   Sweden.
EM kunze@bio.lmu.de

   Atlantic

   Dillwynella voightae [Gulf of Mexico / USA, Louisiana / New species]. 
TN Invertebrates; Molluscs

   Trochoidea

AN ZOOR14705041319
DT Article
TI Peninsular Malaysia's first limbless lizard: a new species of skink of
   the genus Larutia (Boehme) from Pulau Pinang with a phylogeny of the
   genus.
AU Grismer, L. Lee (lgrismer@lasierra.edu) 
   Huat, Evan Quah Seng
   Siler, Cameron D.
   Wood, Perry L., Jr
   Grismer, Jesse L.
   Mohd Sah, Shahrul Anuar
   Ahmad, Norhayati
SO Zootaxa
VL 2799
PS 29-40
PD 24 Mar 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2011/2799.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/2/zt02799p040.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of the scincid genus Larutia, L. penangensis sp. nov.,
   from Pulau Pinang, Peninsular Malaysia is separated from all other
   congeners by having the unique characteristics of the complete absence
   of limbs, four supralabials, large body scales, and no banding or
   striping pattern. Additionally, it has the following unique combination
   of characters that further separates it from all congeners: a single
   presubocular; separated nasals; paired frontoparietals; small, widely
   separated prefrontals; no supranasals or postnasal; two
   postsupralabials; and large, posterior chinshields that contact the
   infralabials. A molecular phylogeny based on one mitochondrial and two
   nuclear genes from all species of Larutia from Peninsular Malaysia
   indicates L. penangensis sp. nov. is most basal and that L.
   seribuatensis is the sister lineage to a clade containing L. miodactyla
   and the sister species L. trifasciata and L. larutensis. Consistencies
   and inconsistencies between this phylogeny and a previously proposed
   morphological phylogeny are discussed.
C1 Grismer, L. Lee; Department of Biology, La Sierra University, 4500
   Riverwalk Parkway, Riverside, California 92515-8247, USA, USA.
EM lgrismer@lasierra.edu
SC Zoology; Evolutionary Biology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Evolution; Land zones; Oriental
   region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Larutia [Phylogeny /  / ]. 
   Larutia penangensis [Malaysia /  / New species]. 
TN Chordates; Reptiles; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Reptilia, Lepidosauria, Squamata,
   Sauria, Scincidae
OR Larutia (Scincidae). 
   Larutia penangensis (Scincidae): [Sp nov, Malaysia, P. 33]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14705041319
DA 2020-09-17
ER

PT J
AN ZOOR14705041322
DT Article
TI Re-description of two atypical species of Pungentus Thorne & Swanger,
   1936, with proposal of Stenodorylaimus gen. n. (Nematoda, Dorylaimida,
   Nordiidae).
AU Alvarez-Ortega, Sergio (saortega@ujaen.es) 
   Pena-Santiago, Reyes
SO Zootaxa
VL 2799
PS 49-62
PD 24 Mar 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2011/2799.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/2/zt02799p062.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Two species of the genus Pungentus originally described by Thorne and
   Swanger (1936), namely P. intertextus and P. textilis, are re-described
   on studying type material. Both species are very similar morphologically
   and characterized by having large general size (body 3.7[long dash]5.1
   mm long), odontostyle comparatively long (about twice the lip region
   width) and slender, with small aperture, relatively short neck (b-ratio
   = 7.0[long dash]9.0), rounded conoid tail, and slightly irregularly
   spaced ventromedian supplements which lack hiatus. This morphological
   pattern significantly differs from that found in other Pungentus
   species, and hence a new genus Stenodorylaimus is proposed to
   accommodate the two species herein studied. Descriptions, measurements,
   line illustrations and LM pictures are provided for both species. The
   new genus is compared in detail with its closest relatives.
C1 Alvarez-Ortega, Sergio; Departamento de Biologia Animal, Biologia
   Vegetal y Ecologia, Universidad de Jaen, Campus 'Las Lagunillas' s/n,
   Edificio B3, 23071 - Jaen, Spain, Spain.
EM saortega@ujaen.es
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type species; Description;
   Combination; Taxonomy; Taxonomic position
TN Invertebrates; Nematodes
ST Animalia, Nematoda
OR Dorylaimus textilis - Thorne & Swanger 1936 (Nematoda): [Designated type
   species for new genus, Stenodorylaimus, p. 60]. 
   Eudorylaimus intertextus - (Thorne & Swanger 1936) (Nematoda): [Referred
   to, New genus Stenodorylaimus, p. 60]. 
   Pungentus intertextus - (Thorne & Swanger 1936) (Nematoda):
   [Redescription, P. 50]. 
   Pungentus textilis - (Thorne & Swanger 1936) (Nematoda): [Redescription,
   P. 54; Referred to, New genus Stenodorylaimus, p. 60]. 
   Stenodorylaimus (Nematoda): [Gen nov, Of subfamily Pungentinae, Type
   species Dorylaimus textilis Thorne & Swanger 1936, p. 60]. 
   Stenodorylaimus intertextus - (Thorne & Swanger 1936) (Nematoda): [Comb
   nov, Transferred from Eudorylaimus, p. 60]. 
   Stenodorylaimus textilis - (Thorne & Swanger 1936) (Nematoda): [Comb
   nov, Transferred from Pungentus, p. 60]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14705041322
DA 2020-09-17
ER

PT J
AN ZOOR14705041320
DT Article
TI A new species of Nemuroglanis (Siluriformes: Heptapteridae) from the rio
   Guariba, rio Madeira basin, Brazil.
AU Ribeiro, Frank Raynner V. (fraynner@yahoo.com.br) 
   Pedroza, Wellington S.
   Rapp Py-Daniel, Lucia H.
SO Zootaxa
VL 2799
PS 41-48
PD 24 Mar 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2011/2799.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/2/zt02799p048.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Nemuroglanis furcatus is described from streams of the rio Guariba, a
   clear water tributary of the rio Aripuana, rio Madeira basin in Brazil.
   Nemuroglanis furcatus can be distinguished from its congeners by the
   possession of a long lateral line, reaching the middle portion of the
   adipose-fin base; a narrow posterior cranial fontanel (16 to 27% of its
   length); and the anterior border of pectoral bridge with a pointed
   contour. The plesiomorphic state of some of the synapomorphies for
   Nemuroglanis in N. furcatus suggests that this species might be the
   sister-group to the remaining species of the genus. A key for all four
   valid species of Nemuroglanis species is provided.
C1 Ribeiro, Frank Raynner V.; Instituto Nacional de Pesquisas da Amazonia,
   Programa de Colecoes e Acervos, Colecao de Peixes, Av. Andre Araujo,
   2936, Petropolis, 69011-970 Manaus, AM, Brazil, Brazil.
EM fraynner@yahoo.com.br
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Key; Land zones;
   Neotropical region; South America
DE Nemuroglanis furcatus [Brazil /  / New species]. 
TN Chordates; Fish; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Pisces, Osteichthyes, Actinopterygii,
   Siluriformes, Pimelodidae
OR Nemuroglanis - Eigenmann & Eigenmann 1889 (Pimelodidae): [Key to
   species, P. 45]. 
   Nemuroglanis furcatus (Pimelodidae): [Sp nov, Brazil, P. 42].

DT Article
TI A new species of Hemus (Majoidea: Majidae: Mithracinae) from the Pacific
   coast of Panama, with a key to the genus.
AU Windsor, Amanda M. (amwindsor@gmail.com) 
   Felder, Darryl L.
SO Zootaxa
VL 2799
PS 63-68
PD 24 Mar 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2011/2799.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/2/zt02799p068.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of spider crab, Hemus magalae n. sp. (Majidae), is
   described from a single male specimen from Islas de las Perlas, Pacific
   Ocean coast of Panama. This species differs from its congeners with
   respect to many features of the carapace including mid-line elevation
   and lateral dentition. Hemus A. Milne-Edwards, 1875, now includes four
   species, three from coastal waters of the eastern Pacific Ocean and one
   from shallow waters in the tropical western Atlantic Ocean. A key to the
   Pacific and Atlantic species of Hemus is provided.
C1 Windsor, Amanda M.; The University of Louisiana at Lafayette, Department
   of Biology, P.O. Box 42451, Lafayette, Louisiana 70504, USA, USA.
EM amwindsor@gmail.com

TI Eriophyoid mites from Hainan Province, China III: Descriptions of three
   new genera and three new species of Colomerini (Acari: Eriophyoidea).
AU Xue, Xiao-Feng
   Cheng, Li-Sheng
   Hong, Xiao-Yue (xyhong@njau.edu.cn) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 2798
PS 37-47
PD 23 Mar 2011

AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/2/zt02798p047.pdf

U1 0
U2 2
AB Three new genera and three new species in the tribe Colomerini of the
   Eriophyidae (Acari: Eriophyoidea) from China's Hainan Island are
   described and illustrated. They are Paraisoannulus machiles gen. nov.
   and sp. nov. on Machilus gamblei King ex Hook. f. (Lauraceae),
   Pentacecidophyes xinglongis gen. nov. and sp. nov. on Litchi chinensis
   Sonn. (Sapindaceae) and Paracaridilophus retusus gen. nov. and sp. nov.
   on Fissistigma retusum (Levl.) Rehd. (Annonaceae). All the new species
   described herein are vagrants on their respective host plant.

   University, Nanjing, Jiangsu 210095, China, China.

   (Pastaza)), A. cuscoata n. sp. (Peru (Cusco)), A. amasanata n. sp. (Peru
   (Amazonas)), A. zoziboucardi n. sp. (Guatemala (Alta Verapaz)), A.

   (Peru (Amazonas)), A. paramelanops n. sp. (Paraguay (Caaguazu)), A.
   parainornatan. sp. (Paraguay (Caaguazu)),A. pomiferoides n. sp. (Peru
   (Amazonas)), A. wernermeisteri n. sp. (Mexico (Oaxaca)), A. knorkeorum
   n. sp. (Mexico (Oaxaca)), A. managuana n. sp. (Nicaragua (Managua)), A.
   jinotegana n. sp. (Nicaragua (Jinotega)), A. juarezia n. sp. (Mexico
   (Oaxaca)), A. altapazia n. sp. (Guatemala (Alta Verapaz)), A. paracelata
   n. sp. (Costa Rica (Puntarenas)), A. choco n. sp. (Colombia (Choco)), A.
   stumpei n. sp. (Costa Rica (Limon)), A. grammocuscoensis n. sp. (Peru
   (Cusco), A. peggyae n. sp. (Peru (Pasco)), A. grammocajamarcensis n. sp.
   (Peru (Cajamarca)), A. grammopiurensis n. sp. (Peru (Piura)), A.
   grammoboliviana n. sp. (Bolivia (La Paz)) and A. occidentorestes n. sp.
   (Ecuador (Pastaza)). All holotypes (ex coll. Ronald BRECHLIN, Pasewalk
   (CRBP), Frank MEISTER, Prenzlau (CFMP) or Eric VAN SCHAYCK [CEvS)) are
   deposited in CRBP in coll. Museum WITT, Munich (Germany), which later,
   together with this collection, will be included in Zoologische
   Staatssammlungen Munchen, Munich, Germany. All the new taxa are
   surrently assigned to species groups sensu LEMAIRE (2002). In addition,
   the following taxa are reinstated from synonymy to species status: A.
   mixtus BOUVIER, 1936 stat. rev. (with its present synonym A.
   eitschbergeri RACHELI & RACHELI, 1999) (removed from synonymy with A.
   larra WALKER, 1855); Automeris rubrescens (WALKER, 1855) stat. rev.
   (with its present synonyms A. nopaltzin SCHAUS, 1892 and A. unilateralis
   BOUVIER, 1936) (removed from synonymy with A. tridens HERRICH-SCHAFFER,
   [1855)); A. vergnei BOUVIER, 1936 stat rev. (removed from synonymy with
   A. duchartrei BOUVIER, 1936); A. peruviana BOUVIER, 1929 stat. nov.
   (originally described as A. godarti (sic) var. peruviana and now removed
   from synonymy with A. cinctistriga (C. FELDER & R. FELDER, 1874)); A.
   pallida BOUVIE.R, 1930 stat. nov. (originally described as a "subspecies
   or form" of A. jucunda (CRAMER, 1779) and now removed from synonymy with
   A. bilinea (WALKER, 1855)); A. occidentalis DRAUDT, 1929 stat. nov. and
   A. hesselorum FERGUSON, 1972 stat. nov. (both removed from synonymy with
   A. iris (WALKER, 1865) and raised to full species rank); A. unifasciatus
   BOUVIER, 1927 stat. rev. (removed from synonymy with A. grammodes
   JORDAN, 1910) and A. serpina BUTLER, 1878 stat. rev. (removed from
   synonymy with A. oresles (BOISDUVAL, 1875)). Finally, the following
   taxa, hitherto treated as subspecies, are raised to species status: A.
   rotunda LEMAIRE, 1971 stat. nov. (from A. amoena (BOISDUVAL, 1875)); A.
   gadouae LEMAIRE, 1966 stat. nov. (from A. zurobara DRUCE, 1886); A.
   argentifera LEMAIRE, 1966 stat. nov. (from A. banns (BOISDUVAL, 1875));
   A. zaruma SCHAUS, 1898 stat. rev. (from A. belti DRUCE, 1886); A. adusta
   HOFFMANN, 1942 stat. nov. (from A. maeonia (DRUCE, 1897)) and A.
   pichichensis LEMAIRE, 1976 stat. nov. (from A. vomona SCHAUS, 1906).

DT Article
TI Four new species in the genus Eubergia Bouvier, 1929 (Lepidoptera:
   Saturniidae).
FT Vier neue Arten der Gattung Eubergia Bouvier, 1929 (Lepidoptera:
   Saturniidae).
AU Brechlin, Ronald (r.brechlin@t-online.de) 
   Meister, Frank
SO Entomo-Satsphingia
VL 4
IS 1
PS 90-94
PD 23 March 2011
PY 2011
LA German
U1 0
U2 0
AB Four new species of the genus Eubergia BOUVIER, 1929 (Lepidoptera:
   Satumiidae) are described and figured: E. sinjaevorum n. sp. (Santa Cruz
   dept.), E. chuquisaciana n. sp. (Chuquisaca dept.) and E. santacruziana
   n. sp. (Santa Cruz dept.), all from Bolivia, and E. altoparanensis n.
   sp. (Alto Parana dept.) from Paraguay. All holotypes (ex coll. Ronald
   BRECHLIN, Pasewalk (CRBP) or Frank MEISTER, Prenzlau (CFMP)) are
   deposited in CRBP in coil. Museum WITT, Munich (Germany), which later,
   together with this collection, will be included in Zoologische
   Staatssammlungen Munchen, Munich, Germany.
C1 Brechlin, Ronald; Friedberg 20, D-17309 Pasewalk, Germany, Germany.
EM r.brechlin@t-online.de
SC Zoology
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Neotropical region;
   South America
DE Eubergia altoparanensis [Paraguay /  / New species]. 
   Eubergia chuquisaciana; Eubergia santacruziana; Eubergia sinjaevorum
   [Bolivia /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; Lepidopterans
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Lepidoptera, Glossata, Heteroneura,
   Bombycoidea, Saturniidae
OR Eubergia altoparanensis (Saturniidae): [Sp nov, Paraguay, P. 91]. 
   Eubergia chuquisaciana (Saturniidae): [Sp nov, Bolivia, P. 90]. 
   Eubergia santacruziana (Saturniidae): [Sp nov, Bolivia, P. 91]. 
   Eubergia sinjaevorum (Saturniidae): [Sp nov, Bolivia, P. 90].

TI Two new species of the genus Hirpida Draudt, 1930 from Peru
   (Lepidoptera: Saturniidae).
FT Zwei neue Arten der Gattung Hirpida Draudt, 1930 aus Peru (Lepidoptera:
   Saturniidae).
AU Brechlin, Ronald (r.brechlin@t-online.de) 
   Meister, Frank
SO Entomo-Satsphingia
VL 4
IS 1
PS 95-98
PD 23 March 2011
PY 2011
LA German
U1 0
U2 0
AB Two new species of the genus Hirpida DRAUDT, 1930 (Lepidoptera:
   Saturniidae) from Peru are described and figured: H. amazonensis n. sp.
   (type locality (TL): Peru, Amazonas dept.) and H. cuscolinea n. sp. (TL:
   Peru, Cusco dept.). Both holotypes are deposited in coll. Ronald
   BRECHLIN, Pasewalk (CRBP) in coll. Museum WITT, Munich (Germany), which
   later, together with this collection, will be included in Zoologische
   Staatssammlungen Munchen, Munich, Germany. The preimaginal instars of
   the new taxa are unknown.
C1 Brechlin, Ronald; Friedberg 20, D-17309 Pasewalk, Germany, Germany.

   zones; Neotropical region; South America

PT J
AN ZOOR14705041068
DT Article
TI Bryodiversity in the tropics: taxonomy of Microporella species (Bryozoa,
   Cheilostomata) with personate maternal zooids from Indian Ocean, Red Sea
   and southeast Mediterranean.
AU Harmelin, Jean-Georges (jean-georges.harmelin@univmed.fr) 
   Ostrovsky, Andrew N.
   Caceres-Chamizo, Julia P.
   Sanner, Joann
SO Zootaxa
VL 2798
PS 1-30
PD 23 Mar 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2011/2798.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/2/zt02798p030.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB The particularly speciose cheilostomate genus Microporella includes taxa
   whose maternal zooids and associated ovicells present a personate
   structure, i.e. a particularly developed peristome. Six species of
   Microporella with personate ovicells are analysed from material sampled
   in the Indian Ocean, Red Sea and southeast Mediterranean. Consideration
   of highly diagnostic tiny morphological characters displayed by the
   primary orifice and the avicularium has made it possible to distinguish
   three new species, M. browni n. sp., M. maldiviensis n. sp. and M.
   collaroides n. sp., and to better characterise the other species. Among
   the latter, two species named by Audouin (1826) from Savigny's drawings
   (1817), M. coronata and M. genisii, are redescribed and neotypes are
   selected. Additionally, a new species of the M. coronata species group,
   Microporella hastingsae n. sp., is proposed following examination of a
   museum specimen recorded as M. ciliata var. coronata (Hastings 1927).
   The species dealt with in this study revealed remarkably different
   patterns of geographic distribution, possibly showing different
   potential for natural and/or anthropogenic dispersal. The bryozoan
   assemblages sampled along the coast of Lebanon include four of the six
   studied species, at least three of them presumably non-indigenous
   including M. harmeri Hayward, which displays a remarkably wide
   distribution from the Indian Ocean to the West Pacific and the East
   Atlantic (Canary Islands).
C1 Harmelin, Jean-Georges; Centre d'Oceanologie de Marseille, UMR CNRS
   6540, Universite de la Mediterranee, Station Marine d'Endoume, 13007,
   Marseille, France, France.
EM jean-georges.harmelin@univmed.fr
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type material; Description; Marine
   zones; Atlantic Ocean; North Atlantic; Indian Ocean; North Indian Ocean
DE Microporella [Marine zones /  / Distribution; systematics; taxa with
   personate maternal zooids]. 
   Microporella browni [Mediterranean Sea / Lebanon / New species] [North
   Indian Ocean / Maldives / ] [Arabian Sea / Djibouti / ] [ / Oman / ]. 
   Microporella collaroides [Red Sea / Egypt / New species] [ / Saudi
   Arabia / ]. 
   Microporella maldiviensis [North Indian Ocean / Maldives / New species].
   
TN Bryozoans; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Bryozoa
OR Flustra coronata - Audouin & Savigny 1826 (Bryozoa): [Neotype
   designated, P. 9]. 
   Flustra? genisii - Audouin & Savigny 1826 (Bryozoa): [Neotype
   designated, P. 13]. 
   Microporella - Hincks 1877 (Bryozoa). 
   Microporella browni (Bryozoa): [Sp nov, Oman (marine), P. 3]. 
   Microporella collaroides (Bryozoa): [Sp nov, Saudi Arabia (marine), P.
   7]. 
   Microporella coronata - (Audouin & Savigny 1826) (Bryozoa):
   [Redescription, P. 9]. 
   Microporella genisii - (Audouin & Savigny 1826) (Bryozoa):
   [Redescription, P. 14]. 
   Microporella hastingsae (Bryozoa): [Sp nov, Type locality not given, P.
   13]. 
   Microporella maldiviensis (Bryozoa): [Sp nov, Maldives (marine), P. 21].
   
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14705041068
DA 2020-09-17

PT J
AN ZOOR14705041069
DT Article
TI A new species of Nymphon Fabricius, 1794 (Pycnogonida: Nymphonidae) from
   northern Spain.
AU Soler-Membrives, Anna (Anna.Soler@uab.cat) 
   Munilla, Tomas
SO Zootaxa
VL 2798
PS 31-36
PD 23 Mar 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2011/2798.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/2/zt02798p036.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of pycnogonid, Nymphon tricuspidatum, is described from a
   slope (574[long dash]610 m depth) on the NE Atlantic coast. Four males,
   two females, five juveniles and nine post-larvae were collected with
   suprabenthic and epibenthic sledges from Le Danois Bank (Bay of Biscay)
   and the Galician waters. This uniunguiculate and brevitarsal species is
   defined by the following exclusive features: a tricuspidated ocular
   tubercle, T-shaped frontal part of the cephalon, lateral implantation of
   the cheliphores, particular denticulation of the chela fingers, the 4th
   palp article smaller than the 5th, and the presence of 2 or 3 cement
   gland tubes. These characters distinguish the species from its most
   similar species Nymphon tubiferum, and the new species is compared to
   other similar species within the same genus, namely N. caementarum, N.
   prolatum, N, puellula and N. caldarium.
C1 Soler-Membrives, Anna; Unitat de Zoologia, Universitat Autonoma de
   Barcelona, 08193, Bellaterra, Cerdanyola del Valles, (Barcelona), Spain,
   Spain.
EM Anna.Soler@uab.cat
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Marine zones; Atlantic
   Ocean
DE Nymphon tricuspidatum [North Atlantic / Spain / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Chelicerates; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Pycnogonida
OR Nymphon - Fabricius 1794 (Pycnogonida): [Diagnostic characters of
   subordinate taxa, Species, p. 34]. 
   Nymphon tricuspidatum (Pycnogonida): [Sp nov, Spain (marine), P. 31]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14705041069
DA 2020-09-17

AN ZOOR14705041072

TI Twelve new species of the Genus Nazeris Fauvel from Zhejiang Province,
   China (Coleoptera, Staphylinidae, Paederinae).
AU Hu, Jiayao
   Li, Lizhen (hujiayaonazeris@gmail.com)

AB Twelve new species of the genus Nazeris Fauvel, 1873 are described from
   Zhejiang Province, China, namely, N. baishanzuensis, N. furcatus, N.
   jiulongshanus, N. lijinweni, N. nigritulus, N. niutoushanus, N.
   parabrunneus, N. shenshanjiai, N. tianmuensis, N. yandangensis, N.

DT Article
TI Species recognition in the genus Scolothrips (Thysanoptera, Thripidae),
   predators of leaf-feeding mites.
AU Mound, Laurence A. (laurence.mound@csiro.au) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 2797
PS 45-53
PD 22 Mar 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2011/2797.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/f/zt02797p053.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 5
AB Species of the genus Scolothrips are re-assessed based on examination of
   type material together with many other specimens, and a key is provided
   to identify the 14 species recognised. The possibility is discussed that
   the three North American species, hoodi, pallidus and sexmaculatus are
   colour variants of a single species. Three apparently Old World species,
   dilongicornis, longicornis and takahashii, cannot be distinguished
   satisfactorily. Three new synonyms are established: quadrinotata is a
   synonym of asura; hartwigi is a synonym of brevipilis; priesneri is a
   synonym of takahashii. Two species from the Canary Islands are
   considered nomina dubia: quadrimaculatus and lanzarotensis. Two species
   are here recorded for the first time from Australia, latipennis and
   rhagebianus, and Australian records of sexmaculatus are considered to be
   based on misidentifications.
C1 Mound, Laurence A.; CSIRO Ecosystem Services, PO Box 1700, Canberra, ACT
   2601, Australia, Australia.
EM laurence.mound@csiro.au
SC Parasitology; Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334

   Parasites diseases and disorders; Hosts; Land zones; Australasian
   region; Australasia; Australia

DT Article
TI Proposal of new specific status for tea-infesting populations of the
   nominal citrus spiny whitefly Aleurocanthus spiniferus (Homoptera:
   Aleyrodidae).
AU Kanmiya, Kenkichi (k_kanmiya@nifty.com) 
   Ueda, Shigenori
   Kasai, Atsushi
   Yamashita, Koji
   Sato, Yasushi
   Yoshiyasu, Sato
   Yoshiyasu, Yutaka
SO Zootaxa
VL 2797
PS 25-44
PD 22 Mar 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2011/2797.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/f/zt02797p044.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 7
AB The citrus spiny whitefly Aleurocanthus spiniferus (Quaintance) is a
   pest of citrus plants that is native to South-East Asia. Although
   serious outbreaks of the tea-infesting whitefly in China, Taiwan and
   Japan have been attributed to this species over the last 20 years,
   recent research has shown different host preferences between the two
   whiteflies. Hence, the two pests have tentatively been differentiated as
   tea-infesting and citrus-infesting populations. We further compared
   morphological, acoustic and genomic features between the two populations
   in Japan. Morphological differences were recognised in the arrangement
   of spines, porettes and papillae on the dorsal disc and number of
   marginal crenulations and marginal waxy fringe of 4th-instar nymphs, as
   well as wing maculation and genitalic organs of adults. In courtship
   behaviour, the acoustic properties of male vibratory signals also
   differed between the two. Furthermore, genetic analysis of mtCOI
   sequences (759 bp) showed that the tea-infesting population was clearly
   distinct from the citrus-infesting group, with high bootstrap values.
   The mtCOI sequence identities were 76.2% between the two populations.
   Genetic differentiation between the two populations was shown by the
   high value (0.99650) of pairwise Fst, indicating the sexual isolation of
   the two populations. Consequently, these two populations are regarded as
   different representatives, consisting of a sibling relationship, but
   clearly distinguished from each other as independent genomic
   populations. Here, we describe the tea-infesting population and propose
   a new scientific name, Aleurocanthus camelliae Kanmiya & Kasai sp. nov.,
   and a new common name, camellia spiny whitefly, thus distinguishing it
   from A. spiniferus (Quaintance), the citrus spiny whitefly that
   constitutes the citrus-infesting population.
C1 Kanmiya, Kenkichi; Institute of Comparative Studies of International
   Cultures and Societies, Kurume University, Mii-machi 1635, Kurume,
   Fukuoka 839-0851, Japan, Japan.
EM k_kanmiya@nifty.com
OI Ueda, Shigenori/0000-0002-6316-2846
SC Parasitology; Zoology; Anatomy &Morphology; Reproductive Biology;
   Genetics &Heredity; Evolutionary Biology; Behavioral Sciences
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; General morphology;
   Reproduction; Reproductive behaviour; Genetics; Evolution; Behaviour;
   Communication; Parasites diseases and disorders; Hosts; Land zones;
   Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Aleurocanthus camelliae [Plant hosts / Camellia japonica / New parasite
   species] [ / Camellia sasanqua / ] [ / Camellia sinensis / ] [ / Cleyera
   japonica / ] [ / Eurya japonica / ] [Japan /  / New species from plant
   host]. 
   Aleurocanthus spiniferus [General morphology /  / taxonomic
   implications] [Courtship / Acoustic courtship signals / ] [Molecular

   [Acoustic signals /  / ] [Plant hosts /  / ] [Japan /  / ].

   Aleurocanthus camelliae - Kaniya & Kasai 2011 (Aleyrodoidea): [Sp nov,
   Japan, Parasite of Camellia sinensis (Plant), p. 28; Parasite].

AB The genus Cylloepus is found in the Nearctic and Neotropical Regions and
   currently represented by 52 species. Twenty species are recorded from
   Brazil, and three of them from Rio de Janeiro State. Here three new
   species of Cylloepus are described[long dash]Cylloepus quinquecarinatus
   sp. nov., Cylloepus nessimiani sp. nov., and Cylloepus friburguensis sp.
   nov. All were collected in the Rio Macae Basin, Rio de Janeiro State,
   southeastern Brazil.

DT Article
TI The genus Haedropleura (Neogastropoda, Toxoglossa=Conoidea) in the
   Plio-Quaternary of the Mediterranean basin.
AU Scarponi, Daniele (daniele.scarponi@unibo.it) 
   Della Bella, Giano
   Ceregato, Alessandro
SO Zootaxa
VL 2796
PS 37-55
PD 21 Mar 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2011/2796.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/2/zt02796p055.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB The Plio[long dash]Quaternary representatives of Haedropleura
   Monterosato in Bucquoy, Dautzenberg & Dollfus, 1883 are revised.
   Protoconch and teleoconch characters of 84 fossil and live-collected
   specimens belonging to the genus, mainly from the Mediterranean basin,
   were quantitatively assessed. The characters examined allow better
   delimitation of variability in the genus along with the recognition of
   eight morphotypes. In particular, four morphotypes were attributed to
   known species: H. septangularis (Montagu), H. bucciniformis (Bellardi),
   H. contii (Bellardi) and H. secalina (Philippi), whereas two are
   described as new species: H. formosa and H. parva. Another two
   morphotypes represented in our material by few, poorly preserved
   specimens remain undescribed. We designate three lectotypes (H.
   bucciniformis, H. secalina and H. septangularis) in order to stabilize
   usage of the names. The Haedropleura a-diversity in the Plio[long
   dash]Quaternary of the Mediterranean basin is also discussed.
C1 Scarponi, Daniele; Dipartimento di Scienze della Terra e
   Geologico-Ambientali, Bologna University, Via Zamboni 67, 40127,
   Bologna, Italy, Italy.
EM daniele.scarponi@unibo.it

DT Article
TI The genus Benthofascis (Gastropoda: Conoidea): A revision with
   descriptions of new species.
AU Tucker, J.K. (jktucker@inhs.uiuc.edu) 
   Tenorio, M.J.
   Stahlschmidt, P.
SO Zootaxa
VL 2796
PS 1-14
PD 21 Mar 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2011/2796.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/f/zt02796p014.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB The conoidean gastropod genus Benthofascis Iredale, 1936 is examined.
   This genus of Conorbidae has extant species. Three previously described
   species from the Recent including the type species B. biconica (Hedley),
   B. sarcinula (Hedley), and B. lozoueti Sysoev & Bouchet are reviewed.
   Three new species from the Recent, B. conorbioides sp. nov., B.
   pseudobiconica sp. nov., and B. angularis sp. nov. are described from
   Australia. One of these (B. angularis) is the first Benthofascis species
   described from Western Australia. Two fossil species originally
   described as Conorbis from the Miocene and Oligocene of Australia (C.
   atractoides Tate and C. otwayensis Long, respectively) are for the first
   time assigned to Benthofascis, thus extending the geologic record of the
   genus to the Oligocene.
C1 Tucker, J.K.; Illinois Natural History Survey, 8450 Montclaire Avenue,
   Brighton, Illinois 62012, USA, USA.

DT Article
TI A new species of Leptolalax (Anura: Megophryidae) from southern Vietnam.
AU Rowley, Jodi J.L. (Jodi.Rowley@austmus.gov.au) 
   Le Duong, Thi Thuy
   Dao, Thi Anh Tran
   Hoang, Huy Duc
SO Zootaxa
VL 2796
PS 15-28
PD 21 Mar 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2011/2796.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/f/zt02796p028.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB We describe a new species of small megophryid frog from the Langbian
   Plateau in southern Vietnam, the southernmost record of Leptolalax from
   Vietnam. Leptolalax bidoupensis sp. nov. is distinguished from its
   congeners by a combination of a dark brownish red ventral surface with
   white speckling on entire ventral surface including throat, arms and
   legs, small size (23.6[long dash]24.6 mm in four adult males and
   29.2[long dash]29.4 mm in two adult females), bicoloured iris (coppery
   red upper half, fading to pale silver ventrally), a mostly smooth skin
   texture with no skin ridges, and relatively short tibia (male TIB:SVL
   0.44[long dash]0.46). The male advertisement call of the new species,
   consisting of 6[long dash]9 single-pulsed notes with a dominant
   frequency of 1.9[long dash]3.8 kHz, is also unique among Leptolalax
   species for which calls are known. From the morphologically similar L.
   applebyi and L. melicus, L. bidoupensis sp. nov. differs by 9.3% and
   9.6% sequence divergence at the 16S mtDNA gene. At present, the new
   species is known from montane evergreen forest between 1620[long
   dash]1730 m elevation, within an area of 1 km2. We suggest the species
   should be considered Data Deficient following IUCN's Red List
   categories.
C1 Rowley, Jodi J.L.; Australian Museum, 6 College St, Sydney, NSW, 2010,
   Australia, Australia.
EM Jodi.Rowley@austmus.gov.au
RI Rowley, Jodi J. L./F-2466-2012
OI Rowley, Jodi/0000-0002-2011-9143

SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Oriental region;
   Eurasia; Asia
DE Leptolalax bidoupensis [Vietnam /  / New species]. 
TN Amphibians; Chordates; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Amphibia, Lissamphibia, Anura,
   Pelobatidae
OR Leptolalax bidoupensis (Pelobatidae): [Sp nov, Vietnam, P. 17]. 
DI 10.11646/zootaxa.2796.1.2

TI A new genus and species of Cheyletidae (Acariformes: Prostigmata) from
   citrus trees in Florida.
AU Xia, Bin (xiabin9@163.com) 
   Klompen, Hans
   Childers, Carl C.

LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB A new genus and species, Lanceacheyla whartoni (Acariformes:
   Prostigmata: Cheyletidae) is described for the female, male, and
   teleonymph. All mites were collected from leaves of 'Hamlin' orange
   trees in Florida, U.S.A. Affinities of the new genus within Cheyletidae
   are discussed.

DT Article
TI A new Aceria species (Acari: Eriophyoidea) on Echinops ritro L. subsp.
   ruthenicus (M. Bieb.) Nyman (Asteraceae) from Serbia and a supplement to
   the original description of Aceria brevicincta (Nalepa 1898).
AU Vidovic, Biljana (magud@agrif.bg.ac.rs) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 2796
PS 56-66
PD 21 Mar 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2011/2796.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/2/zt02796p066.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB A new species of eriophyoid mite, Aceria banatica n. sp. inhabiting
   Echinops ritro L. subsp. ruthenicus (M.Bieb.) Nyman has been described
   from Serbia. A comparison of characters between A. banatica n. sp. and
   Aceria echinopsi Boczek and Nuzzaci 1988, the only other species known
   from Echinops sp., is given. A supplementary description of Aceria
   brevicincta (Nalepa 1898) found on Jurinea mollis (L.) Rchb. in Serbia
   is included along with a comparison of taxonomic characters of this
   population with previously described specimens from Hungary and the poor
   original description from Austria.
C1 Vidovic, Biljana; Department of Entomology and Agricultural Zoology,
   Faculty of Agriculture, University of Belgrade, Nemanjina 6, 11080
   Belgrade [long dash] Zemun, Serbia, Serbia.
EM magud@agrif.bg.ac.rs
SC Parasitology; Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334

   disorders; Hosts; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Europe
DE Aceria banatica [Plant hosts / Echinops ritro ruthenicus / New parasite
   species] [Serbia /  / New species from plant host]. 
   Aceria brevicincta [Plant hosts / Jurinea mollis / Systematics] [Serbia
   / Deliblato Sands / ].

DT Article
TI Additions to the Hyperaspis Chevrolat (Coleoptera: Coccinellidae) fauna
   of South American, descriptions of nine new species, and recognition of
   Hyperaspis pectoralis Crotch as a valid species.
AU Gordon, Robert D. (rdgordon@utma.com) 
   Gonzalez, F. Guillermo
SO Insecta Mundi
VL 0160
PS 1-20
PD March 18 2011
PY 2011
UR http://centerforsystematicentomology.org/insectamundi/0160GordonandGonza
   lez.pdf
AW http://centerforsystematicentomology.org/insectamundi/0160GordonandGonza
   lez.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Nine new species of Hyperaspis from various South American localities
   are described, illustrated, and compared with previously described taxa.
   New taxa are: Hyperaspis luciae, H. corcovado, H. divaricata, H.
   humboldti, H. mimica, H. praecipua, H. unimaculosa, H. drechseli, and H.
   esmeraldas. Hyperaspis pectoralis Crotch is recognized as a valid
   species of Hyperaspis and integrated into the existing classification.

   ND 58384, USA, USA.

DT Article
TI Tribe Teruliini: new genera and new species of Neotropical leafhoppers
   with a revised key to genera and species, new records and notes on
   distribution and taxonomy (Hemiptera: Cicadellidae: Coelidiinae).
AU Nielson, M.W. (mwnielz@comcast.net) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 2795
PS 1-45
PD 18 Mar 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2011/2795.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2011/1/zt02795p045.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Two new genera, Freytagolidia, type-species Freytagolidia ligula sp.
   nov. and Neodocalidia, type-species Neodocalidia connectiva sp. nov.,
   from Colombia are described and illustrated. Nineteen additional new
   species are described and illustrated in the following genera: Baluba
   sharkeyi sp. nov. (Colombia), Bolidiana robusta sp. nov. (Colombia), B.
   trisetacea sp. nov. (French Guiana), B. elongata sp. nov. (Colombia),
   Harasupia lyrata sp. nov. (Mexico), Hastalidia acinaca sp. nov. (Peru),
   Jalorpa constricta sp. nov. (Colombia), Licontinia minutasetacea sp.
   nov. (Colombia), L. recurvata sp. nov. (Panama), Panolidia torquersi sp.
   nov. (Colombia), P. minuta sp. nov. (Colombia), Sapingia calcaris sp.
   nov. (Colombia), Stalolidia flangella sp. nov. (Colombia), S. semiovata
   sp. nov. (Colombia), S. setacea sp. nov. (Colombia), S. ecuadorensis sp.
   nov. (Ecuador), S. lyrica sp. nov. (Bolivia), S. clava sp. nov. (Brazil)
   and S. bulbata sp. nov. (Peru). Taxonomy and distribution of genera,
   revised key to species and details on new records are provided. A
   revised key to all known genera is also included. Colombia is a new
   record for Baluba, Jalorpa, Panolidia, Sapingia and Stalolidia; Panama
   for Licontinia; Peru for Hastalidia and Ecuador for Stalolidia. The
   type-species name, Coelidia marginata Stal, for Harasupia Nielson, 1979
   was incorrectly cited as Harasupia marginata (Stal) and is corrected
   herein.

   84602, USA, USA.
